{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127577,"name":"Daniel Quednow","username":"Dannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c2a13f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T19:19:21.464Z","cooked":"

I was wondering whether there is any way to deadzone a joystick based on the magnitude of its position from its resting point. In the new way WPILib works with triggers, you no longer override a get method but instead pass in a boolean supplier.

new Trigger(whatever::isActive);

One thing I can do is put a deadzone around the individual axes, but that results in a square deadzone, not a circular one.

Some of the things I tried were

  1. Keeping the same code, and just passing in a reference to the get method. This didn’t work because you can’t reference super or this in the super call.
  2. Wrapping everything in an object, keeping one reference to it in the derived class, and passing a method to the super constructor. This didn’t work because the super call needs to be the first thing in a constructor.
  3. Finally, I tried creating the objects using a factory and hashes to keep track, and abstract it to a method to allow for calling it on one line. This did work, but it feels very hacky.
  4. Another solution would be to keep the object, and just have the trigger as a property, but again, that feels very hacky.

So, my question gets to be, is there any clean way that I might be able to achieve what I am looking for?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T19:19:21.464Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":134,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":698.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423430,"topic_slug":"creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude","display_username":"Daniel Quednow","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56386,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude/423430/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3127586,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T19:41:48.064Z","cooked":"

I’m not clear on why there’s a super call involved here at all? Trigger is intended to be used as-is, without subclassing. You can write whatever logic you want in the BooleanSupplier you pass to it.

But also, why are your joystick axes interacting with Trigger in the first place? Ordinarily a deadband would be handled in processing of whatever uses the joystick, rather than in command scheduling logic…

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T19:46:35.754Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":100,"readers_count":99,"score":20.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423430,"topic_slug":"creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude/423430/2","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3127595,"name":null,"username":"Starlight220","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T19:47:28.142Z","cooked":"

I’m not sure what you’re trying to achieve here. If it’s an axis deadzone, I don’t see how Trigger is relevant.
Also, if you’re using a flight joystick with the Joystick/CommandJoystick class, the getMagnitude method might be of use.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T19:47:28.142Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":107.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423430,"topic_slug":"creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":45763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6738a | ISR | WPILib"},"post_url":"/t/creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude/423430/3","custom_user_title":"6738a | ISR | WPILib","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3127601,"name":"Daniel Quednow","username":"Dannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c2a13f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T19:59:47.260Z","cooked":"

Generally, what I am trying to achieve is using the trigger as is, but adding other useful methods to it, to keep things grouped together. So, I might use the trigger itself by just activating it once the magnitude is greater than some value, but I want to add other methods to the trigger to allow for easier access to what the trigger is actually doing. So, I might be using the joystick on an Xbox controller, and only want it to trigger something after it’s a certain distance away from zero, but also have the ability to get the deadzoned values from the same object. Just trying to keep like things in like places.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T19:59:47.260Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":15.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423430,"topic_slug":"creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude","display_username":"Daniel Quednow","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56386,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude/423430/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3127605,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T20:10:04.815Z","cooked":"

This seems like it violates separation of concerns pretty badly. The point of Trigger is to schedule commands; you should not be creating a subclass of Trigger that does other things on top of that. That’s not an intended API interaction and you’ll have to fight the library to do it.

It’d be easier to provide feedback if you could share your code.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T20:10:26.982Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":61,"readers_count":60,"score":62.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423430,"topic_slug":"creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude/423430/5","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3127631,"name":"Sam Belliveau","username":"Sampajama","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sampajama/{size}/180943_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T20:43:05.672Z","cooked":"

You can use simple pythagorean theorem to find the distance of the stick.

new Trigger(
    () -> Math.sqrt(
            joystick.getLeftX() * joystick.getLeftX() +
            joystick.getLeftY() * joystick.getLeftY()
        ) >= 0.25
    );

or if you have a magnitude function for your stick

new Trigger(() -> stick.magnitude() >= 0.25);

This is pseudo code, I don’t know what your code base looks like but i’m sure you can adapt this.

Generally if you want a command do be able to read from a gamepad you have to pass in the gamepad to the command.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T20:48:09.912Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423430,"topic_slug":"creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude","display_username":"Sam Belliveau","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39415,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Sam"},"post_url":"/t/creating-a-deadzone-based-on-magnitude/423430/6","custom_user_title":"Sam","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3127644,"name":"Daniel Quednow","username":"Dannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c2a13f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T20:59:59.983Z","cooked":"

Through talking with my mentor, we eventually decided that (after looking more thoroughly through the changes in the new WPILib code) trying to link the joystick directly with command based went against the new way that WPILib is made, and we made the decision to leave it to the end effector to create the triggers rather than trying to link them directly in the class themselves. Allowing for easy composition with command based programming, but not relying on it.

Oblarg:

This seems like it violates separation of concerns pretty badly.

Yeah… we came to that same conclusion. Thank you for your help, everyone.
